title: Incomplete sanitization pool volume
vignette: The town pool holds only thirty-eight liters of water, shy of the required forty.

options.text: Add collected water until it reaches forty liters before use.
Use it anyway since it's close to the minimum.

title: Mixing tap water first
vignette: Workers accidentally pour three buckets of tap water into the empty pit before any rainwater falls.

options.text: Disqualify it; tap water must not precede the rainwater.
Add plenty of rainwater later and use it.

title: Pipe-fed sanitization bath
vignette: A new bath uses pipes to bring rainwater directly from the roof.

options.text: Piped water is acceptable if not pumped by vessels.
Only naturally gathered water counts; pipes invalidate.

title: Painted walls flaking
vignette: Paint chips fall into the sanitization pool as people bathe.

options.text: The flakes are negligible; continue using it.
Stop use until the paint is removed and water replaced.

title: Standing vs flowing water
vignette: A spring feeds the pool but the water becomes stagnant during the summer.

options.text: As long as it's spring water, bathing is valid.
It must be flowing at treatment time to count.

title: Cracked basin leaking
vignette: Small cracks cause the pool to slowly leak below forty liters overnight.

options.text: Repair it and refill before the next use.
Use while water remains, even if below measure later.

title: Treatment of utensils
vignette: Merchants dip new metal cups in the pool one after another without drying them first.

options.text: Utensils may be treated even consecutively without issue.
Moisture from each contaminates the next; dry them first.

title: Using melted snow
vignette: Snow is gathered and melted to top off the pool during a drought.

options.text: Melted snow counts as natural water and is fine.
Only direct rainfall is acceptable; reject the snowmelt.

title: Heated water added
vignette: They warm some rainwater before pouring it into the cold pool.

options.text: Heating does not disqualify; mix it in.
Once heated, it's tap water and invalid.

title: Portable treatment tub
vignette: A traveler fills a large barrel with rainwater to use as a personal sanitization bath on the road.

options.text: A movable container cannot serve as a valid sanitization pool.
If it holds forty liters, it works wherever it sits.

title: Pool built by contractors
vignette: Local workers who are not specialists dig and plaster the new treatment bath.

options.text: Construction by anyone is fine if specifications are met.
Only a specialist-built pool is reliable for treatment.

title: Doubtful measurement
vignette: After renovations, nobody recalls whether the pool was measured accurately.

options.text: Re-measure to ensure forty liters before further use.
Assume it remains valid based on past use.

title: Animal carcass falls into the pool
vignette: A small animal dies and is found floating in the water.

options.text: Discard the water and sanitize the basin before reuse.
Scoop out the carcass and continue using the water.

title: Shared clothing at treatment
vignette: People borrow communal robes to wear when bathing because they own none.

options.text: Borrowed garments are fine if they are clean.
Each person must own personal clothing for the treatment.

title: Treatment at twilight
vignette: Someone finishes bathing just as the sun sets, leaving doubt whether it was day or night.

options.text: It counts for that day since part was before sunset.
Repeat at clear daylight to avoid any question.
